title: 105_hr3497
content: The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" establishes individual investment accounts under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" allows individuals to deduct cash payments made to individual investment accounts established for their benefit. An individual investment account is a trust in the U.S. exclusively for an individual, with specific requirements for contributions and trustee qualifications. The trustee of the individual investment account must be a bank or qualified person, assets cannot be invested in collectibles, and assets cannot be mixed with other property except in specific funds. Contributions are deemed made on the last day of the taxable year if made by the prescribed time. Contributions to individual investment accounts are deemed made on the last day of the taxable year if made by the prescribed time. Distributions from these accounts are generally included in gross income unless they qualify as a first-time homebuyer distribution. Qualified 1st-time homebuyer distribution allows individuals to use payments from an individual investment account for qualified acquisition costs towards a principal residence. The total amount for such distributions cannot exceed $20,000. Qualified 1st-time homebuyer distributions are limited to $20,000 in aggregate for all taxable years. The basis of the principal residence is reduced by the amount of the distribution. Transferring an individual's interest in an investment account to a former spouse due to divorce is not considered a taxable transfer. Transferring an individual's interest in an investment account to a former spouse under a divorce decree is not taxable. The account will be treated as the spouse's individual investment account thereafter. Individual investment accounts are exempt from taxation unless they cease to qualify as such. Individual investment accounts are exempt from taxation unless they cease to qualify as such by engaging in prohibited transactions. If an individual violates IRS rules with their account, it will lose its tax-exempt status. If an individual engages in prohibited transactions with their individual investment account, it will lose its tax-exempt status and be treated as distributing all its assets. If an individual uses their individual investment account as security for a loan, the portion used will be treated as distributed to that individual. Rollover contributions are allowed if the amount is paid into another individual investment account within 60 days. Cost-of-Living Adjustment is also considered. The $20,000 amount in subsection (c)(2)(B) will be increased for taxable years after 1998 based on the cost-of-living adjustment. The taxable year begins by substituting `calendar year 1997' for `calendar year 1992' in subparagraph (B). Dollar amounts not multiples of $10 are rounded to the nearest multiple. Custodial accounts are treated as trusts if held by a bank or person meeting specific criteria. The trustee of an individual investment account must report to the Secretary and the account holder on contributions, distributions, and other matters as required by regulations. Deductions are allowed in arriving at adjusted gross income. The trustee of an individual investment account must report to the Secretary and the account holder on contributions, distributions, and other matters as required by regulations. Deductions are allowed in arriving at adjusted gross income, and individual investment accounts are exempt from estate tax. "SEC. 2046. INDIVIDUAL INVESTMENT ACCOUNTS." Individual investment accounts are excluded from the gross estate value and are not subject to Section 1014. A special rule exempts individuals from tax on prohibited transactions related to these accounts if the account ceases to be an individual investment account. Individual investment accounts are exempt from gross estate value and Section 1014. A special rule prevents taxation on prohibited transactions if the account no longer qualifies as an individual investment account. Amendments are made to failure to provide reports on individual retirement accounts or annuities. Amendments are made to failure to provide reports on individual investment accounts and the adjustment of basis for a residence acquired through the use of an account. Amendments are made to failure to provide reports on individual investment accounts and the adjustment of basis for a residence acquired through the use of an account. The table of sections for part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Code is amended by adding a new paragraph related to the acquisition of a residence with funds from an individual investment account. The table of sections for part III of subchapter A of chapter 11 of the Code is amended to include new items related to individual investment accounts and disclaimers. The amendments made by this section will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1997.
